Award.AwardTitle: Influence of stormwater management structures on ecological function in urban streams

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this research is to test the hypothesis that stormwater Best Management Practices (BMPs) positively influence ecosystem function of urban streams at multiple spatial and temporal scales. This project will assemble a comprehensive set of measures to determine the impact of BMPs on water quality in several urban watersheds. Interdisciplinary aspects include water quality analyses, stream morphology, and ecological monitoring and modeling. Placement, design, and density of BMPs will be investigated to determine the optimal benefit for stream ecosystem services, such as nutrient uptake, metabolism, temperature and biological indices. The results of monitoring BMPs will be combined with ecological modeling of nutrient concentrations to identify the areas best served by BMPs and how well the BMPs function to achieve the over-arching goal of improved stream health. Inclusion of thermal pollution is an important component of this research. Undergraduate students will be heavily involved, and will gain experience in design of environmentally friendly BMPs. The involvement of a stakeholder group will transfer the results to people who can use the results to influence current stormwater regulation and management practices.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Insights into the effects of stormwater control measures (SCMs) on urban stream hydrology and in-stream processes are required to understand their effectiveness in mitigating the environmental problems associated with urbanization. These impacts include reduced drinking water quality, infrastructure damage due to flooding and erosion, and general loss of ecosystem services. Through an integrated and synergistic monitoring and modeling approach, we isolated the effects of individual SCMs as well as the cumulative effect of multiple SCMs on hydrologic and ecosystem response at the reach and watershed scales. We found that the level of urbanization was the primary control on the hydrologic, water quality and ecosystem response metrics we assessed. A common measure of urbanization is the total amount of impervious cover in a watershed. We found that total imperviousness controlled the size and duration of stream flow during storms. However, over annual cycles, mitigation by SCMs and percent of the watershed with tree coverage were also important. To isolate the effects of individual SCMs on in-stream processes, we developed a novel approach using stable isotopes and showed that water stored in stormwater ponds was predominantly released at the end of the storm following peak flows. This leads to lower nutrient concentrations and dynamic temperature changes in streams receiving water from SCMs when compared to watersheds without SCMs. In addition, SCMs and in-line ponds increased nitrogen removal via denitrification in receiving streams, but only in watersheds with relatively low impervious cover. This likely results from the combined effects of modified water chemistry and increased channel stability at high levels of impervious cover. Similarly, biotic integrity as measured by macroinvertebrate populations was strongly linked with total impervious cover. Together, our results demonstrate that the observed benefits of current stormwater mitigation practices may not match the scale of the problem, while underscoring the consensus that urbanization has far-reaching consequences for water resources. This has important implications for management of urban watersheds. Indeed, limitation of watershed imperviousness together with increased mitigation by SCMs will be necessary to alleviate the impacts of urbanization on stream ecosystems.

Through this research, we have provided essential information to planners and water resource managers in the Southeastern U.S. to guide decisions on placement of SCMs and to identify optimum locations for restoration efforts. The project has also supported the training of 10 science and engineering students, providing them with a state-of-the-science interdisciplinary education on urban water resources. Through our broader impacts in public education and outreach, including leading exhibitions at the North Carolina Science and Technology Expo, we have increased understanding and awareness of water quality issues in urban areas where many residents are disconnected from their natural resources. Raising awareness of the importance of water in urban areas and connecting citizens of all ages to their natural environment is the best path toward a sustainable and productive urban ecosystem.
